markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

madison.com  (WEB - en-US)

A website covering local news in Madison, Wisconsin, and hosting content from the Wisconsin State Journal and The Capital Times.  

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership or Financing

Madison.com is owned by Capital Newspapers, a publishing company owned by the parent companies of the two papers that provide the majority of its content, the Wisconsin State Journal and The Capital Times.

The Wisconsin State Journal is owned by Lee Enterprises, a publicly traded company that owns more than 40 daily newspapers, including the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Lee Enterprises newspapers generate revenue from advertising and subscriptions to their print and digital editions. The Capital Times is owned by The Capital Times Company.

The two organizations have worked together since 1948, when they consolidated printing and central business operations.

Content

Madison.com is a hub for politics, crime, lifestyle, sports, and entertainment coverage for Madison, Wisconsin’s state capital and for the surrounding area, posting content from the Wisconsin State Journal, The Capital Times, along with some content original to the site. A podcast section also features content from both newspapers. The Associated Press supplies national and international stories. 

Credibility

Madison.com articles are fact-based, typically based on original reporting and citing multiple sources. The Wisconsin State Journal lists 47 reporters and editors on its staff page, while The Capital Times lists a staff of nine reporters and eight editors. The Contact Us page on Madison.com lists four staff members, including a web reporter.

The site publishes opinion content from both the Wisconsin State Journal and The Capital Times, which is clearly labeled.

No formal corrections policy is listed on the site, but corrections made to stories are appended at the end of articles or, when the mistake involved a photograph, in the photo caption.

The Wisconsin State Journal was named as a finalist in 2012 for a Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Reporting for its coverage of union protests at the state capitol.

Transparency

Ownership of Capital Newspapers is disclosed on the Capital Newspapers page on Madison.com.

The Contact pages includes the names, email addresses, and phone numbers for staff members, as well as general email address and phone numbers for various departments. Advertising is are clearly labeled.  

History

The Wisconsin State Journal began as an afternoon paper called The Madison Express in 1839, adopting its current name in 1860. Lee Enterprises bought the paper in 1919. The Capital Times was founded in 1917 as a direct competitor to the Wisconsin State Journal by the latter’s former managing editor William T. Evjue.The two papers combined printing and central business operations in 1948 under Madison Newspapers Inc., now Capital Newspapers.

The Capital Times ceased daily publication of its print edition in 2008. It now largely focuses on its website while still offering a weekly print edition.  

Madison.com was launched in 1996. 

Written by:
John Gregory

Edited by:
Peggy Ackermann Eric Effron
